castAddBody.text: Still getting a sense for the audience and the conversation.
Does Farcaster have client-agnostic permalinks? Does Warpcaster expose them somewhere?
Oh here's one: I can't copy anything from the Android app.
I seem to be in the best shape of my life. Not saying much, but I'm going to keep doing what I'm doing.

Would Steve Randy Waldman's idea of taxing price rather than value be an example of a protocol?

https://www.interfluidity.com/v2/4911.html

Walk everyday. Eat fruit and/or veggies before each meal.

I think you already do these. My standards have just been lower. I can jog a little bit without my knees hurting for the first time in years.
I don't particularly prefer either, but Discord seems to be having a moment in my neighborhood in 2023.

Low-traffic either

High-traffic neither
Whoa, I just found the URL for a cast behind the 'upload' button on bottom right.
Unclear if there's a way to navigate to a URL though. I'm on the Warpcaster Android app.
SJIM/LJIM still cracks me up.
Support selecting and copying text from casts.
Seems like a startup.
I don't follow this. Did QE give middle class money or dam it up?
Sounds like Terraform deployments.
Polytheism is good.

Minor quibble: <moleman>I'm anti-crypto.</moleman>

But I try to keep an open-ish mind.

Drawing a family tree for the kids using this new tool I made.

https://git.sr.ht/~akkartik/snap.love https://i.imgur.com/zQT1VGy.png
You have a problem. The AI says, "I know, I'll use regular expressions." Now you have two problems.
Mistakes are good. Reduce consequences of mistakes so people can fearlessly make more of them and learn from them. Don't take away consequences entirely so people stop learning.
I have no moat and I must scream.

https://world.hey.com/dhh/even-amazon-can-t-make-sense-of-serverless-or-microservices-59625580 feels broadly correct, but has some epicycles. SOA vs microservices is a spectrum, not black and white. Here's a cleaner way I think about things.

The essential software question of the last 50 years: how to split up the tech parts to minimize communication between people.

Teams that talk frequently among themselves should deploy together. Teams that don't need a service boundary so they can deploy separately.

Among other things, this answers how much utilization to aim for. Every service boundary is a place to introduce slack. If a single team owns too many (>10) tiny services, you get clusters running at 5% utilization. If too many teams share a single service monolith, everyone moves slower.

Splitting and merging service boundaries as orgs reorg is the critical skill. Splitting/merging services in unanticipated ways is why we need tests. Tech debt = software map lags the people territory.

It needs to be somebody's job (the CTO's?) to obsessively focus on this one metric, to adjust everything through this lens. The CEO/business has found product-market fit, a customer, a goal worth of an organization. The tech org executes toward the goal. The CTO's job is to not fuck up the org.

For example, hiring. A team deploying a service splits into 2 = ok. 10 teams shipping a shared monolith = none of them gets to hire until some new service boundaries are drawn up. People who talk together should ship together, to within an order of magnitude.

</soapbox>

Deals with the devil would work so much better if:

* There were multiple competing devils;
* You could publish reviews of your experience; and
* They depended on repeat business from you.

The trouble with the One Ring is really just the first word. Smeagol was a captive audience.

https://monoskop.org/images/e/ee/Cramer_Florian_Words_Made_Flesh_Code_Culture_Imagination.pdf

I can copy a set of nested bullets from Obsidian to LogSeq, but the other direction loses all nested structure. Do others find paste working fine?
